Literature Review: The interplay between working memory and selective attention has been a topic of increasing interest in cognitive neuroscience. This literature review explores the concept of 'inside-out' attention, focusing on how selective attention operates within working memory to guide behavior, with a particular emphasis on visual working memory.Working memory (WM) is a limited-capacity system that temporarily maintains and manipulates information for ongoing cognitive tasks. Traditionally, research has focused on how attention selects information from the external environment to be encoded into WM, a process often referred to as 'outside-in' attention. However, there is growing recognition of the importance of 'inside-out' attention, which involves the modulation of WM contents to guide behavior (Souza & Oberauer, 2016).The purpose of inside-out attention is multifaceted. Firstly, it allows for the prioritization of task-relevant information within WM. Myers et al. (2017) demonstrated that participants could selectively attend to specific items in visual WM, enhancing their representation and improving subsequent task performance. Secondly, inside-out attention facilitates the flexible updating of WM contents in response to changing task demands. Rerko and Oberauer (2013) showed that attention could be redirected to different items in WM, allowing for rapid shifts in behavioral priorities.The targets of inside-out attention are diverse and can include various features of visual information stored in WM. Color, orientation, and spatial location are commonly studied attributes. For instance, Heuer and Schubö (2016) found that participants could selectively attend to either color or orientation information within WM, depending on task requirements. Moreover, Theeuwes et al. (2011) demonstrated that attention could be directed to specific spatial locations within visual WM representations.The sources of inside-out attention are both internal and external. Internally generated goals and task demands can drive the allocation of attention within WM. Griffin and Nobre (2003) showed that participants could use self-generated cues to orient attention to specific items in visual WM. External cues can also guide inside-out attention. Retro-cues, presented after the initial encoding of information into WM but before recall, have been shown to effectively direct attention to specific WM contents (Souza et al., 2014).The mechanisms underlying inside-out attention are still being elucidated. One prominent theory suggests that attention acts as a 'gatekeeper' for WM, controlling both the encoding and maintenance of information. Vogel et al. (2005) provided evidence for this view, showing that individual differences in the ability to filter out irrelevant information predicted WM capacity. Another perspective posits that attention serves to strengthen or 'refresh' WM representations. Johnson et al. (2015) used neuroimaging to demonstrate that directing attention to items in WM reactivated their neural representations, potentially supporting their maintenance.The study of inside-out attention has significant implications for our understanding of both attention and WM. It challenges the traditional view of WM as a passive storage system, instead highlighting its dynamic and flexible nature. LaRocque et al. (2013) proposed that WM might be better conceptualized as a form of internal attention, blurring the lines between these two cognitive processes.Furthermore, the investigation of inside-out attention provides insights into how cognitive processes support adaptive behavior. By allowing for the flexible manipulation of mental contents, inside-out attention enables the anticipation of future events and the preparation of appropriate responses. Stokes et al. (2009) demonstrated that attention to WM contents could bias perceptual processing, facilitating the detection of expected stimuli.In conclusion, the study of inside-out attention represents a significant shift in our understanding of how WM serves behavior. It emphasizes the active, flexible, and future-oriented nature of cognitive processes. As research in this area continues to evolve, it promises to provide a more integrated view of attention and WM, offering new perspectives on how the mind guides action in complex, dynamic environments.
